In the course of the conversation, it seems that the Rabonon agree that R’ Yehoshua has a legitimate point, but they want to know how he explains his position when there is no evidence of cohabitation. In reality we must deal with the fact that the Rabonon do hold that even when there is evidence of cohabitation, she is permitted to marry a Kohain. Why is this different than a captive girl, where they agree that she is forbidden to a Kohain? Tosfos now addresses this question:
The explanation of the Rabonon in step 4) is: According to us it is easy to explain the difference between a captured girl and a young lady who is now pregnant from an unknown man, because a woman who is promiscuous examines the lineage of her partner and then is promiscuous. Even though she wants to cohabit, she does not want to become forbidden to marry a Kohain. She is therefore particular about her partner in cohabitation. This is not comparable to a captive girl, who has no choice in the matter, she is totally controlled by her idolater captors and must submit to them. Thus, we assume that she was disqualified from marrying a Kohain.
The Rabonon continue their attack on R’ Yehoshua: However, according to you, who does not hold of this thinking and you are therefore concerned that her partner was a nosin/mamzer, this is logical when she is pregnant and you are sure that she cohabited with her unknown partner, but when she secluded herself, even according to your opinion, there is a difference between the case of a captured girl and the young lady who willingly secluded herself with an unknown partner, for in the case of [the captive girl] there are witnesses that she cohabited1This evidence is based on the assumption that idolater captors would definitely force her to submit to them. and in the case of the girl who secluded herself with an unknown partner there are no witnesses about cohabitation and even when she admits that she cohabited with him, but claims that he was of pure lineage, she has a migo that she could have denied cohabiting with him.
R’ Yehoshua said to them: The מדברת - who secluded herself with an unknown partner is the same as a captive girl in regard to claiming that she did not cohabit with her partner, and just as we do not believe a captive girl who says I did not cohabit with my captor, so too, when a מדברת - young lady who secluded herself with an unknown partner claims that she did not cohabit with him, we do not believe her, as [the Gemara] concludes - because there is no guarantor that can prevent illicit relations. The certainty of cohabitation in both cases is equal. The captured young girl, because the idolaters who captured her are licentious when it involves their pleasure, and the young lady who secluded herself, because the temptation is too great to overcome. We may therefore assume that she cohabited with her unknown partner.
Tosfos has now concluded that we would not believe a young lady who secluded herself with an unknown partner, even if she denied cohabiting with him. In Tosfos on 13a ד"ה ואין אוסרין, we learned otherwise. However, this explanation of the dialogue between R’ Yehoshua and the Rabonon is not viable according to our explanation earlier (Tosfos 13a ד"ה אין אוסרין), that according to R’ Yehoshua, we believe [the young lady who secluded herself] when she says “I did not cohabit” with my partner. The conclusion of the dialogue between R’ Yehoshua and the Rabonon is in direct contradiction to Tosfos’ earlier conclusion. The Gemara here would be saying that according to R’ Yehoshua we do not believe her when she denies cohabiting with her partner, whereas Tosfos concluded earlier that we definitely do believe her when she denies cohabitation.
Due to Tosfos earlier conclusion that even according to R’ Yehoshua when the young lady denies cohabiting with the suspected unknown partner, we do believe her, we must find a way of reading our Gemara, so that it will concur with Tosfos’ ruling. Let us remember that Tosfos’ position was that we do not believe the young lady when she claims:
A) I did have relations with the unknown man, but he was of pure lineage, even though she has a migo that could have claimed that
B) she did not have relations with him at all.
Even though we would believe her denial, it cannot be used as a migo to prove her present claim, that he was of pure lineage. Why not?
Tosfos suggests that our Gemara when explaining that מדברת היינו שבויה - the girl who was secluded is equal to a captive girl, because there is no guarantor that can prevent illicit relations, is explaining why the migo is not effective, even though we would believe her if B) she denied having relations with the unknown partner.
R’I explains even though his explanation is admittedly awkward, that when R’ Yehoshua says: The young lady who secluded herself with an unknown partner is just as the captive girl, he means that just as the captive girl is assumed to have cohabited with her captors, so too, the girl who secluded herself is assumed to have cohabited with her unknown partner, but only insofar as if she says, the man with whom I cohabited was of pure lineage, we do not believe her with a migo that she could have denied having relations with him, because she is afraid to say: I did not cohabit with him, since she assumes that it is not likely that people will believe her, she is afraid to deny cohabitation. Thus, there is no migo that she could have denied having relations with her unknown partner. However, if she actually did deny cohabitation, we would believe her, but she feels that her denial would ring untrue.
It is for this, to negate the migo, that the argument “there is no guarantor that can prevent illicit relations” is effective, because we do not consider her alternative, to claim that she did not cohabit with the unknown partner, a proper migo, even though we would believe her if she denied having relations with her unknown partner.

[This supports] the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi.
See introduction to the previous Tosfos, where I outlined four steps of the dialogue between R’ Yehoshua and the Rabonon. There is a fifth step which we will now discuss.
5) R’ Yehoshua argues the a girl who secludes herself with a man is similar to a captive girl, because there is no guarantor that can prevent forbidden relations.
The Gemara proves from this conversation that the meaning of מדברת - she was speaking, is that she secluded herself with an unknown man, but not that there was evidence that she cohabited with him.
The Gemara than asks: But let R’ Yehoshua derive a difference between the two cases, because in the case of the captive girl, the majority of her captors would disqualify her from marrying a Kohain because they are idolaters. Whereas, in the case of a girl secluding herself with an unknown man in a Jewish city, the majority of people who might have cohabited with her would not disqualify her from marrying a Kohain.
The Gemara explains: This supports R’ Yehoshua ben Levi’s statement, that Rabban Gamliel is lenient even when the majority are those who would disqualify her and R’ Yehoshua is stringent even when the majority are those who would not disqualify her. The Gemara later on 14a will elaborate on this point. Thus, R’ Yehoshua’s argument to the Rabonon is: You are lenient even when the majority of men who might have cohabited with her would disqualify her. Why is this different than a captive girl, where you agree that she may not marry a Kohain?
Tosfos points out that there still is a major difference between the two cases. In regard to the captive girl, all her captors are idolaters, who by cohabiting with her disqualify her from marrying a Kohain. In the case of the girl who secluded herself with an unknown man, even if it was in a ruin in the fields, where we must consider the possibility that her partner came from the general population of the world, there is still the possibility of a minority of would be partners who would not disqualify her?
Rabbeinu Tam asks: Even if we accept R’ Yehoshua ben Levi’s statement that the Rabonon are lenient even when she secluded herself with an unknown partner in a ruin in the fields where the majority are men who would disqualify her, still, let [R’ Yehoshua] derive a difference between the captive girl and the girl who secluded herself with an unknown partner as follows: For there in the case of the captive girl, all men who might have cohabited with her would disqualify her, because they are all idolaters, but here in the case of seclusion in a ruin in the field, of all the men who might have cohabited with her there are only a majority that would render her unfit, but there is still a minority that would not disqualify her?
[Rabbeinu Tam] answered: That insofar as rendering her unfit to marry a Kohain, a majority of men who would disqualify her is the same as if all men who might have cohabited with her are unfit.
Tosfos will now suggest that perhaps there truly is a difference between when all those men that might have cohabited with her are unfit and when they are only a majority. This distinction is based on a Gemara in Kiddushin 80a.
In order to understand the Tosfos further, we must be familiar with the Gemara that Tosfos quotes from Kiddushin 80a. Usually, when we learn an imported Gemara, I explain it according to Rashi. However, since this Tosfos is the opinion of Rabbeinu Tam I will explain it as he does in Kiddushin 80a ד"ה שדרכו.
For we learned in a Mishna: A toddler who was found next to a dough, and there is a little piece of dough in his hand. The toddler is definitely tomay because he is constantly in contact with women who are niddos. But how did the dough get into his hand? Did he take it himself, thus making the entire dough tomay, or perhaps a tahor person took it from the pile and gave it to him, and the remaining dough is tahor? R’ Meir says that the pile of dough is tahor and the Rabonon say it is tomay, because it is the norm for a toddler to touch the dough himself and he most probably took the piece of dough himself and in the process made the rest of the dough tomay.
We thought into this matter, what is R’ Meir’s reason? He holds: Most toddlers do touch the dough, but a minority do not touch the dough. The status quo of this dough is that it is tahor. There is a conflict between the majority that says the toddler touched the dough and the status quo that says the dough remained tahor. Put the minority of toddler who do not touch the dough, together with the status quo that the dough remained tahor, the majority that the dough became tomay is weakened.
Thus, according to R’ Meir, the rule that we follow the majority is in effect only when there is no chazakah opposing it. However, when there is a chazakah that combines with the minority, they are equal to the majority.

Minority + chazakah = majority

The Rabonon who disagree with R’ Meir hold that in all cases we follow the majority, even when there is a chazakah opposing it.
Tosfos will now suggest that perhaps there really should be a difference between a captive girl, where all of her captors would disqualify her and the girl who secluded herself, where although there is a majority of men who would disqualify her, there is however a minority of men who would not disqualify her. Perhaps we should put the chazakah together with the minority and annul the majority.

Minority of men who would not disqualify her
+ chazakah that she was fit for a Kohain till now
= majority of men who would disqualify her

It cannot be said that in regard to a girl who secluded herself where there is only a majority of men who would disqualify her, but there is also a minority that would not disqualify her, we should say: put the minority of men who would not disqualify her, together with the status quo and the majority that says he was a man who would disqualify her is weakened. For even if Rabban Gamliel and R’ Yehoshua both hold1Obviously, according to the Rabonon who disagree with R’ Meir in Kiddushin 80a, we cannot entertain the idea that there may be a difference between when all would disqualify her and when only a majority would disqualify her. Tosfos is pointing out that even R’ Meir who is lenient in the case of an equal doubt in tumoh, is not lenient in a doubt of prohibitions. that we do combine the minority of men who would not disqualify her, with the chazakah that she was permitted to a Kohain till now, and the combination invalidates the majority of men who would disqualify her, even so, the effect of the combination is to make the chances half and half, and by law she should be forbidden to her husband, because there remains an equal doubt and when there is an equal doubt in matters pertaining to prohibitions, we must be stringent. This is not similar to a toddler who was found beside a dough in Perek Asoroh Yuchsin (Kiddushin 80a) where we rule that the dough is tahor because we combine the minority with the chazakah and rule leniently.
But why don't we compare this case of a doubt in matters of prohibitions to the case of a doubt in matters of tumoh? For if [the Rabonon] said in regard to a doubt about tumoh that we will be lenient when there is an equal doubt, would they say the same about a doubt in matters of prohibitions, that we should also be lenient? Certainly, not as [the Gemara] says in Perek Kisui Hadam (Chulin 86b). The Gemara there specifically addresses a question comparing the laws of a doubt in prohibition and a doubt in matters of tumoh and says that they are not comparable.2The basis of the difference between doubts of tumoh and doubts in prohibitions is discussed in Tosfos Chulin 86b ד"ה סמוך. The laws of doubts in matters of tumoh are derived from the laws governing a suspected adulteress. The Gemara explains that when there is a doubt in a matter of tumoh that comes about because of the involvement of “one who cannot be asked” whether the item became tomay or not, we are lenient. The toddler is considered “one who cannot be asked” and since the doubt came about because of his involvement, we rule leniently. This distinction between doubts of different natures, is in effect only for tumoh, but not for prohibitions, where we are always stringent.

He renders her fit [to marry a kohain], even where the majority [of the men in her proximity] are unfit. As we have seen in the previous Tosfos, R’ Yehoshua in the fifth step of the dialogue, argues that a captive girl and a girl who was secluded with an unknown partner are comparable. The Gemara then asked: But are they truly comparable! In the case of a captive girl, the majority that might cohabit with her are idolaters, who disqualify her from marrying a Kohain, whereas, in the case of the girl who was secluded, the majority of men who might have cohabited with her would not disqualify her.
The Gemara responds, based on R’ Yehoshua ben Levi’s statement, that the Rabonon permit the girl who was secluded with an unknown man to marry a Kohain even when the majority would render her unfit, such as in a ruin in the fields where the majority of the world must be taken into account, and they are certainly mostly unfit. It is in reference to this case that R’ Yehoshua argued that it is comparable to a captive girl, where the Rabonon agree that she is prohibited to a Kohain.
A simple reading of this Gemara yields that Rabban Gamliel rules the girl fit even when she was secluded when a majority of her would be partners would render her unfit, but Tosfos finds a Gemara in Kiddushin 74a, where it seems that Rabban Gamliel ruled that the girl who was secluded is permitted only when there was in fact a majority who would not render her unfit.
In order to understand this Tosfos, we will need to acquaint ourselves with a Gemara in Kiddushin 74a. The Gemara refers to a statement by Abba Shaul who says that the class of people whom the Rabonon called שתוקי - the “silenced”, because their mothers would silence them when asked about their paternity, indicating that they are forbidden to inter-marry with regular Israelites, are truly called בדוקי - “examined”, because they are allowed to inter-marry not only with regular Israelites, but even with Kohanim, when their mother claims that her partner was of pure lineage.
The Gemara there says that the dispute is about Rabban Gamliel’s ruling in our Mishna. Rabban Gamliel rules that we accept the testimony of the girl who was secluded and her children are permitted, whereas the Rabonon do not accept her testimony and their status remains in doubt. What does Abba Shaul mean with the word “examined”? If you say that it means that when we interrogate his mother and she says that I cohabited with one who is fit and I am still permitted to marry a Kohain, we believe her. According to whom is this so? According to Rabban Gamliel. The Gemara asks: But we already learned this once? As we learned in a Mishna: If she was pregnant and they said to her: What is the nature of this fetus? She said to them: From that person and he is a Kohain, i.e. his lineage is pure. Rabban Gamliel and R’ Eliezer say: We believe her. R’ Yehoshua says: It is not from her mouth that we live, i.e. we do not believe her and the status of her fetus is in doubt. Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: The halacha follows Rabban Gamliel.
Rashi there explains that there was no need for Abba Shaul to express his opinion in the Mishna in Kiddushin, the Mishna in Kesubos after citing Rabban Gamliel should have just said that Abba Shaul holds the same as Rabban Gamliel.
Eventually, the Gemara answers: The statement of Abba Shaul is stronger than that of Rabban Gamliel. For if we only had the statement of Rabban Gamliel there in Kesubos, I would say that his ruling is in effect only when there is a majority who are fit for her and do not render her unfit to a Kohain. However, when the majority is unfit for her - I would say that she may not marry a Kohain. Therefore, it was necessary for Abba Shaul to state his opinion in Kiddushin 74a to ascertain that even when the majority is unfit we accept her testimony that her unknown partner was fit.
A simple reading of the Gemara in Kiddushin 74a says that Rabban Gamliel is t lenient only when there is a majority who are fit for her. It is only Abba Shaul who holds that even when the majority is unfit, we accept her testimony. Our Gemara in Kesubos 13b clearly says that Rabban Gamliel is lenient even when there is a majority of men who are unfit for her. But that which [the Gemara] says in Perek Asarah Yuchsin (Kiddushin 74a) in regard to Abba Shaul who called the class of “silenced” - “examined”. The Gemara explains that he is speaking of those whom when we investigate his mother about the paternity of her child. she says - “I cohabited with a man who is fit” and produced this child. We believe her and her child may marry whomever he or she pleases.
[The Gemara] then asks: According to whom is it so? According to Rabban Gamliel. But we have already learned this once in our Mishna in Kesubos: If she was pregnant etc. [and we asked her: what is the status of this fetus? She responds: I cohabited with a man who is fit. Rabban Gamliel and R’ Eliezer say: we believe her. R’ Yehoshua says: We do not live from her mouth.] The explanation of the Gemara’s question is: The Mishna in Kesubos 13a should have taught: And so too, did Abba Shaul say, since he is in agreement with Rabban Gamliel. Why was this mentioned at all in the Mishna in Kiddushin? So too, Rashi explained the Gemara’s question there in Kiddushin 74a.
[The Gemara] answers: That Abba Shaul’s ruling is stronger than Rabban Gamliel’s ruling. For if we only had Rabban Gamliel’s ruling in the Mishna there in Kesubos 13a, I would say that this leniency is in effect only when the majority of would be partners were fit for her etc. [but when they are mostly unfit, I might say, no!, we do not believe her]. It is quite clear that the Gemara in Kiddushin 74a is saying that from our Mishna we could only know that Rabban Gamliel’s lenient ruling is in effect when there is a majority of men who are fit for her. But our Gemara says that Rabban Gamliel’s ruling is in effect even when the majority are unfit for her? Even though [the Gemara] here says that Rabban Gamliel rules that she is fit even when there are a majority of unfit, if so, why does the Gemara in Kiddushin say that from our Mishna we would only know that Rabban Gamliel is lenient only when there is a majority of men who are fit for her?
Tosfos explains: Abba Shaul is referring to what is clearly stated in our Mishna, and from our Mishna there is no indication at all that it is speaking of when the majority of her would be partners are unfit for her. The deduction that Rabban Gamliel permits her to a Kohain even when there is a majority of unfit partners, comes from the Baraisa in our Gemara, but not from the Mishna itself. Since Rabban Gamliel does not mention it specifically in the Mishna, it is fair to say that this was Abba Shaul’s addition to the ruling.
However, upon further examination of the Gemara there in Kiddushin 74a, there seems to be a difficulty. Earlier in the Gemara in Kiddushin 74a, the Gemara responds to the question “what did Abba Shaul add?” as follows: Rabban Gamliel’s ruling comes to teach that she is fit to marry a Kohain. Abba Shaul’s ruling comes to teach us that even her daughter is fit to marry a Kohain.
The Gemara asks: That is fine according to the one who says that [Rabban Gamliel] who rules that [the mother] is fit to marry a Kohain, prohibits her daughter from marrying a Kohain. It can then be said that Abba Shaul is adding that even the daughter is permitted to marry a Kohain. But according to the one who says that [Rabban Gamliel] who rules that she is fit to marry a Kohain also rules that her daughter is fit to marry a Kohain, what is Abba Shaul coming to teach us? The Gemara then says that Abba Shaul is adding that even when there is a majority of unfit, she is permitted to a Kohain.
Even though the fact that Rabban Gamliel permits her daughter to marry a Kohain is not specifically mentioned in the Mishna, the Gemara considers it a valid rejection of the argument that Abba Shaul’s novelty is that even the daughter is permitted. But Tosfos has just said that since the ruling that Rabban Gamliel permits her even when there was a majority of unfit people is not specifically mentioned in the Mishna, we can answer that Abba Shaul’s novelty is that she is permitted even when there was a majority of unfit people, if so, why couldn’t the Gemara say that Abba Shaul’s novelty is that her daughter is also permitted, since it is not specifically mentioned in the Mishna?
That which [the Gemara] asks earlier, there in Kiddushin 74a, when [the Gemara] attempts to say that Abba Shaul comes to add that her daughter is fit to marry a Kohain: That is fine according to the one who says that [Rabban Gamliel] who rules [the mother] fit to marry a Kohain, rules that her daughter is unfit to marry a Kohain. Since Rabban Gamliel holds that the daughter is unfit, it is logical to say that Abba Shaul is teaching us that even the daughter is fit to marry a Kohain. However, according to the one who says that [Rabban Gamliel] who rules that she is fit to marry a Kohain also rules that her daughter is fit, how can it be said that Abba Shaul comes to add that her daughter is also fit? Since Rabban Gamliel also holds that her daughter is fit, what is Abba Shaul adding?
But according to Tosfos’ explanation earlier, since Rabban Gamliel’s leniency in regard to her daughter is not specifically mentioned in the Mishna, it can be said that Abba Shaul’s novelty is that her daughter is also fit? Just as we say that since Rabban Gamliel does not specifically mention in the Mishna that she is permitted to a Kohain even though there was a majority of those who would render her unfit, it is justifiable to say that Abba Shaul is adding this novelty, even though Rabban Gamliel concurs with Abba Shaul’s position, so too, since Rabban Gamliel did not specifically mention in the Mishna that her daughter is also fit, it is justifiable to say that this was Abba Shaul’s addition, even though Rabban Gamliel agrees?
There in the earlier part of the dialogue in Kiddushin 74a, [the Gemara’s] question is fine, for even according to Zeiri,1The Gemara on 13a says that according to Rav Asi, the second part of the Mishna that speaks about a young unmarried lady who is pregnant, is teaching us that the Mishna’s intention is to teach us that Rabban Gamliel permits even the daughter to marry a Kohain. Tosfos is now adding that even though we are not compelled to say this according to Zeiri, the simple translation of the Mishna indicates that this is true even according to Zeiri.2I have followed Maharshal’s emendation of our Tosfos as it is printed in our Gemaros. See מהרש"א for an alternate reading. from the text of the Mishna which reads: “What is the status of this fetus?” it is to be understood that [Rabban Gamliel] is coming to rule that her daughter is fit to marry a Kohain. Otherwise, why is the Mishna discussing the fetus at all? This reference to the fetus is saying that Rabban Gamliel is also ruling that her daughter is fit. If so, what is Abba Shaul adding?

It is obvious [that we dismiss the claims of the ‘son’]. Do we know who fathered him?
There is a similar Gemara in Kiddushin 75a: As we learned concerning a betrothed woman who became pregnant: Rav Says the child is a mamzer and Shmuel says the child is a “silenced one”.
A bit later in the dialogue the Gemara asks: But what does Shmuel mean when he refers to the child as a “silenced one”? Does he perhaps mean that we silence his claim that he is an heir to his father’s estate?
The Gemara then asks: That is obvious. Do we know who his father really is? Certainly not!
The Gemara answers: It is only necessary to inform us that he is not entitled to a share in his father’s estate when he already seized the assets. Shmuel is teaching us that even though he is already in possession of what he claims is a share of his father’s estate, his claim is silenced.
It seems that our Gemara could have used the same answer as Kiddushin 75a. That Shmuel is teaching us that even though the ‘son’ already took possession of the estate’s assests, he is silenced and his claim is useless. Here, [the Gemara] does not want to answer “it was only necessary for Shmuel to teach us that the 'son’ is silenced from his claim that he is an heir when he already seized the property in question”, as the Gemara answered to this very question in Perek Asoroh Yuchsin (Kiddushin 75a) in regard to a betrothed woman who was pregnant. For there in the case of a betrothed woman who was pregnant, there are grounds to believe that she was impregnated by her betrothed, and there is reason to assume that it was he who impregnated her more so than other men. It is therefore necessary for Shmuel to inform us that even so, and even when he already seized the property in dispute, we silence his claim.
However, in our Gemara, where there is a one out of ten possibility that the deceased fathered this son and we have no special reason to believe that it was in fact the deceased who fathered him, there is no need for Shmuel to teach us that his claim is disregarded.

We require that his seed be pedigreed after him. The Gemara concludes that even when we are certain that a person is definitely the offspring of a Kosher Kohain, we ‘silence’ him from his right to serve in the Bais Hamikdosh as a Kohain, because one of the prerequisites for service is that his lineage must be traceable. It is not enough to be certain that he was born of a Kosher Kohain. We must know that he is the son of a particular father. When we do not know who his father is, he cannot serve in the Bais Hamikdosh.
It follows that whenever a Kohain’s paternity is in question, he cannot serve in the Bais Hamikdosh. There is a contradiction to this conclusion in Yevamot 37a. That which [the Gemara] says in Hacholetz (Yevamot 37a) in regard to the possibility that a Kohain is the child of a Kohain who passed away seemingly childless, whose brother then performed yibum and subsequently it was discovered that his mother was pregnant and there is a question that perhaps [the child] is the son of the first husband, and he was born after nine months of pregnancy or perhaps he is the child of his brother, the second husband, born after seven months of pregnancy and in either case the issue of a Kosher Kohain. The Baraisa rules that the first child of the second brother is suitable to be a Kohain Gadol, because we know that no matter whether he is the child of the first husband or the second husband, he is the son of a Kosher Kohain. It seems that even though we are unaware of exactly who his father is, he can serve in the Bais Hamikdosh. This contradicts our Gemara that says even though we know that all the Kohanim who might have cohabited with this lady were Kosher, the child cannot serve in the Bais Hamikdosh, because because his lineage is not traceable to his father.
Tosfos explains: In Perek Nosin al Hanusah (Yevamot 100b) [the Gemara] asks this question and answers: the requirement that one’s seed must be traceable to [his father] is inherently Rabbinic, and the verse cited as proof of this requirement is merely offered as support of the Rabbinic decree, but is not truly a derivation from the verse. [The Rabonon] only instituted this decree when the child in question is the product of promiscuity as it is in our Gemara in Kesubos 13b, however, when the child is a product of a legitimate marriage as in Yevamot 37a, the Rabonon did not decree that the child should not be allowed to serve in the Bais Hamikdosh.

That Chosson and his Kallah. At the conclusion of our Gemara on 14a, the Gemara rules:
A) That we are not concerned that the Kallah might have cohabited with another man who fathered this child, because the Chosson admitted that he had relations with her.
B) Even if we did not have the admission of the Chosson,1This does not mean that the Chosson denied paternity. If he denied paternity, we would not believe the mother. The Gemara means that we did not discuss the issue with the Chosson and he is presently unavailable. We must rule based only on the information we receive from his mother. See Rosh here and Shulchan Aruch E.H. 4, 27 and Gra there 64 & 67. Rav Yehudah in the name of Shmuel ruled that we follow Rabban Gamliel who says that the we believe the Kallah who claims that the child is legitimate.
Our Gemara is not the only Gemara that deals with this issue. The Gemara in Kiddushin 75a and in Yevamot 69b also speaks about similar situations. A superficial reading of all these Gemaros might lead one to believe that they are contradicting each other. Tosfos takes us by the hand and leads us through all these passages and ultimately shows us how they are not contradictory.
I quote verbatim only the Gemara in Kiddushin 75a. As we learn the Tosfos we will becomes sufficiently aware of the Gemara in Yevamot 69b. The Gemara in Kiddushin 75a speaks about a similar situation, but the conclusion seems to differ with what we have concluded here in Kesubos 14a. As Tosfos says later, the text of the Gemara in Kiddushin that he is quoting is not the text that we have printed in our edition of the Gemara. The quote – הבא על ארוסתו בבית חמיו appears in our Gemara in Yevamot 69b (version 1).
Tosfos will reconcile the differences between the two Gemaros. We learned concerning one who cohabited with his betrothed in the house of his father-in-law: Rav says the child is a mamzer and Shmuel says the child is a “silenced”one.
At this point in the dialogue of the Gemara, both Rav and Shmuel hold that there is a serious question about the paternity of this child and he or she is not permitted to marry a Yisrael. Their dispute is only whether the child is a definite mamzer or whether there is only a doubt that he might be a mamzer.
Eventually, the Gemara offers another interpretation of Shmuel’s opinion: If you want, I can say another explanation of Shmuel’s use of the word שתוקי - a silenced one. What did Shmuel mean when he used the word שתוקי? He meant that he has been - investigated! When we investigate his mother about the lineage of the child’s father, she responds: I cohabited with a kosher man, who did not render me unfit to marry a Kohain. We believe her and she and her child are allowed to be married to a Kohain.
The Gemara continues: In accordance with whom did Shmuel rule that we believe the mother? In accordance with Rabban Gamliel.
According to this text of the Gemara in Kiddushin, Shmuel initially ruled that when we know that a Chosson cohabited with his Kallah before the Chuppah, the child would be forbidden to marry a Yisrael because we are concerned that he is a mamzer. This definitely contradicts our Gemara, where it seems that the child is even permitted to marry a Kohain.
Tosfos at this point assumes that when the Gemara in Kiddushin says: A Chosson cohabited with his Kallah in his father-in-law’s home, the implication is that we know of this cohabitation because he admits that this is so. Therefore, it is exactly the same as our Gemara, which speaks of a Chosson who admits that he fathered his Kallah’s child. We must therefore differentiate between the two cases. That which [the Gemara] says in Perek Asoroh Yuchsin (Kiddushin 75a): We learned: Concerning one who cohabited with his Kallah in his father-in-law’s home i.e. during the period of betrothal. Rav says: the child is a mamzer. Shmuel says: The child is a “silenced” one, which means that there is only a reasonable doubt that he might be a mamzer, but he is not definitely a mamzer.
That Gemara is speaking of when they did not investigate his mother, for if they investigated his mother, and she insists that her child is her Chosson’s, there is a contradiction between Shmuel in Kiddushin 75a and Shmuel here in Kesubos 13b. For Shmuel says here in Kesubos 14a that we believe the Kallah because the halacha follows Rabban Gamliel that we believe her, and there in Kiddushin [the Gemara] says we must reverse the opinions and Shmuel says the child is a mamzer. Obviously, there must be some difference between the two cases, and Tosfos holds that the difference is that in Kesubos the mother was investigated and testified that the child is kosher, whereas in Kiddushin the mother was not investigated and we have no way of investigating her now. We are forced to rule without the testimony of the mother and the child is therefore declared a mamzer.
So it seems that the initial ruling of the Gemara there is based on the lack of testimony from the mother, for at the conclusion of the exchange the Gemara answers: Actually we need not reverse etc. [the opinions of Rav and Shmuel] and the Gemara there explains Shmuel’s statement as follows: What did he mean when he referred to this child as שתוקי - a “silenced’ one? That we investigated his mother and she says that I cohabited with a kosher man and our child may even marry a Kohain. It definitely seems that in its initial understanding of the case, the Gemara assumed that the mother had not been investigated. Under those circumstances, it was understandable that that Shmuel ruled the child a mamzer. When the Gemara eventually concluded that Shmuel was speaking of when the mother had testified in favor of the legitimacy of her child, it concluded that the child is kosher. This concurs with Shmuel’s opinion here, that we rule in favor of Rabban Gamliel who says that we must believe the mother about the paternity of the child.
As we mentioned earlier Tosfos understands that in the Gemara in Kiddushin we know of the Chosson cohabiting with his Kallah by his own admission, which is exactly the same situation as in our Gemara. If so, there is still a huge difference between the conclusion of both Gemaros.
We must remain aware that our Gemara clearly states that there are two distinct reason for ruling that the Chosson is the father of the child:
A) He admitted paternity.
B) The Kallah as well insists that the Chosson is the father.
It appears from our Gemara that each of these reason is independently sufficient to rule that the child is the son of the Chosson. If you ask: We have still not resolved the contradiction between the two Gemaras about Shmuel’s opinion, for there in Kiddushin 75a it appears that only when there are two factors:
A) by his own admission the Chosson cohabited with his betrothed in his father-in-law’s home,
B) investigating the Kallah, accomplishes that we rule the child is kosher. There must be a combination of both the Chosson’s admission and the Kallah’s testimony.
However, here in Kesubos it seems that even when the Chosson does not admit1This does not mean that the Chosson denied paternity. If he denied paternity, we would not believe the mother. The Gemara means that we did not discuss the issue with the Chosson and he is presently unavailable. We must rule based only on the information we receive from his mother. See Rosh here and Shulchan Aruch E.H. 4, 27 and Gra there 64 & 67. that he is the father, Shmuel says that we believe the Kallah, in accordance with Rabban Gamliel who rules that we believe the mother even when we have not heard from the Chosson at all, such as in the case of the unknown partner, where we did not hear from the father.
In order to reconcile Shmuel’s stated opinions, we must say that the case in Kiddushin, where both father and mother testify about the legitimacy of her child was not described that way to accommodate Shmuel. Shmuel would hold that even if we only have the testimony of the mother, the child is kosher. But why did the Gemara there create the scenario including the father’s admission as well?
We can answer: That the reason [the Gemara] in Kiddushin mentioned that we know that the Chosson cohabited with his Kallah by his own admission, is because it is a greater novelty according to Rav that it was mentioned. That even so, that both Chosson and Kallah testify that the Chosson fathered this child, [Rav] says the child is a mamzer. However, according to Shmuel, even if we have only the testimony of the mother, the child is not only legitimate, but may even marry a Kohain.
Tosfos now offers another distinction between the Gemara in Kiddushin and our Gemara in Kesubos, so that there should be no contradiction between the two positions of Shmuel. This distinction initially appears in Yevamot 69b, where the Gemara is dealing with a Mishna in Yevamot 69a that says: When a Kohain cohabited with an unmarried girl his child may eat Terumah. It is clear that even though she was not married to this Kohain, we believe her when she says that he is the father. This stands in contradiction to Rav and Shmuel’s ruling that even when Kallah and Chosson agree about the paternity of their child, his lineage is in doubt and he is declared unfit to marry even a Yisrael.
Rava there suggests that Rav and Shmuel are speaking of when there are rumors that the Kallah cohabited with others and the Mishna is speaking of when there are no rumors that the single girl cohabited with other men. Tosfos will now use Rava’s explanation of Rav and Shmuel in Yevamot 69b to resolve the contradiction between Shmuel’s statements.
Alternatively, there in Kiddushin 75av it is required that we know by his own admission that the Chosson cohabited with the Kallah, and only then will we believe the Kallah who says that the Chosson fathered this child, because [the Gemara in Kiddushin] is speaking of when there are rumors that she was promiscuous not only with her Chosson, but with others as well. Since there are rumors that she cohabited with others, it is necessary that both Chosson and Kallah testify that the child is legitimate as Rava says in Yevamot at the end of Perek Almanah L’Kohai Gadol (69b): It is reasonable that Rav’s statement is speaking of when there are rumors that she was generally promiscuous. However, here in Kesubos we are speaking of when there are no rumors that she was generally promiscuous and that is why Shmuel believes the testimony of the Kallah alone when she testifies that her unknown partner was of kosher lineage.
Tosfos will now concede that this entire exercise was needed only according to a single manuscript in Kiddushin that speaks of one who cohabited with his betrothed. All other manuscripts tell a different story. Furthermore, in all manuscripts the text in Kiddushin (75a) reads: A betrothed Kallah who became pregnant. There is no mention of the Chosson admitting that he was the father of this child. We can now understand that it is specifically in that case, when we have not heard from the Chosson1This does not mean that the Chosson denied paternity. If he denied paternity, we would not believe the mother. The Gemara means that we did not discuss the issue with the Chosson and he is presently unavailable. We must rule based only on the information we receive from his mother. See Rosh here and Shulchan Aruch E.H. 4, 27 and Gra there 64 & 67. that [the Gemara] says that we must investigate the Kallah, but when we know that the Chosson cohabited with the Kallah by his own admission, investigating the Kallah is unnecessary. Thus, there is no contradiction between the two statements of Shmuel.
Tosfos has spoken of two different texts about the dispute between Rav and Shmuel in Kiddushin. Actually both of these cases appear in Yevamot 69b as variant versions of the dispute between Rav and Shmuel. Abaye in Yevamot 69b holds that even when there are no rumors that the Kallah was promiscuous with other men, the child is prohibited even to a Yisrael. According to Abaye we cannot say that the difference between Yevamot (version 1) where Shmuel is stringent and Kesubos where Shmuel is lenient is because Yevamot (version 1) is speaking of when there were rumors about the Kallah’s activity with other men and Kesubos is speaking of when there were no rumors, because Abaye holds that in Yevamot (version 1) Shmuel rules stringently even when there are no rumors of activity with other men. How will Abaye resolve the two conflicting statements of Shmuel? In Kesubos Shmuel rules that either the Chosson’s admission or the Kallah’s testimony is sufficient to permit the child to marry even a Kohain, whereas in Yevamot 69b, Shmuel rules that even in the absence of rumors, even when Chosson and Kallah testify that the child was fathered by the Chosson, he is ruled illegitimate.
However, there is a difficulty with the first version of Rav and Shmuel’s dispute in Yevamot 69b, at the end of Perek Almanah L’Kohain Gadol, where Rav and Shmuel argue when we know by his own admission that the Chosson cohabited with the Kallah. Abaye concludes there in Yevamot 69b that even though there were no rumors that [the Kallah] was generally promiscuous, Rav and Shmuel argue about the status of the child, but both agree that he may not marry a Yisrael, because perhaps just as she was promiscuous with her betrothed, so too she may have been promiscuous in general and we have no idea who the father really is. It emerges that according to Abaye even when the Kallah is not known to have been promiscuous with others, we are still concerned that she may have been with others besides her Chosson.
But [the Gemara] here says: One reason that the child is kosher is because the father admits that it was he, who fathered the child. It seems that according to this reason the child is kosher even according to R’ Yehoshua.2The Gemara on 14a says that even without the father’s admission Shmuel rules like Rabban Gamliel that we must believe the mother. It seems that according to the first analysis that the father admitted his paternity, the child is kosher even according to R’ Yehoshua. What is the difference between these two Gemaras according to Abaye?
Tosfos’ question that there is a contradiction between the two Gemaros is dependent on the circumstance of each Gemara being the same. At this point Tosfos needs to ascertain that the cases are in fact similar. The Gemara in Yevamot (version 1) speaks of one who ‘cohabited’ with his betrothed. Our Gemara speaks of the Chosson ‘admitting’ that he fathered the child. And the expression ‘he cohabited’ used in Yevamot 69b, means the same as the expression ‘he admitted’ used here in Kesubos. For the expression ‘he admitted’ fathering the child used here, means only that he says he cohabited with her. It certainly does not mean that he was tailing her, to lie in wait for her in order to insure that she was not promiscuous with others.3See שיטה מקובצת who quotes other Rishonim who hold that the Chosson’s testimony about the paternity of the child is effective only if he says “her hand did not move from my hand” i.e. we were constantly together and she definitely did not cohabit with anybody else. Tosfos assumes that the expression ‘he cohabited’ with her in Yevamot means that we know this by his own admission, not by testimony of witnesses. Ultimately Kesubos rules that when the Chosson admits that he fathered the child, we accept his testimony even according to R’ Yehoshua, but Yevamot seems to be saying otherwise, that according to both Rav and Shmuel, the child is forbidden to marry a Jewess by birth4A mamzer may not marry those who are Jewish by birth. He may however, marry converts to Judaism. for the term “silenced” that Shmuel says, means that he is forbidden to marry a Jewess by birth according to all5The Gemara in Kiddushin in one version says that even according to Rav, who refers to the child as a mamzer, he is not permitted to marry a definite mamzeress, since it is not certain that he is a mamzer. If so, what does Shmuel mean when he refers to the child as a “shetuki - silenced” one? Usually that term is reserved for a dubious mamzer, whi is not permitted to marry a definite mamzer or a Jewess by birth. In what way is Shmuel differing with Rav? The Gemara offers a few suggestions of how Shmuel’s appellation - “shetuki - silenced” one is to be understood. According to all suggestions there, with the exception of the very last one, Shmuel holds that the child is a dubious mamzer and may not marry a Jewess by birth. Tosfos refers to those explanations of Shmuel as “all the versions”. The very last interpretation of Shmuel, is that if we investigate his mother and she testifies that he is kosher, we believe her. Tosfos refers to this last interpretation of Shmuel as - ‘the version that he was ‘investigated’. versions of the Gemara mentioned in the last Perek of Kiddushin. And according to the version in Kiddushin 75a, that says Shmuel meant “an investigated” child, i.e. his mother was investigated about the lineage of her fetus and testified that he was kosher, there is also a great difficulty, for it is to be understood that even when the father has been investigated as evidenced by the Gemara’s use of the expression ‘he cohabited’, which we know by his own admission, the child is kosher only according to Rabban Gamliel, because the Gemara there specifically says that our investigation of the mother is effective only according to Rabban Gamliel, but according to R’ Yehoshua, we do not believe the mother. Whereas, here [the Gemara] says in its analysis of the case, that when [the Chosson] admitted that he fathered the child, he is kosher according to all opinions. It is only when the Gemara says that even if he did not admit paternity, we believe the mother, that the Gemara introduces Shmuel’s ruling in favor of Rabban Gamliel. It is a fair assumption that when the Gemara was ruling that the child is kosher based on the father’s admission, it means that he is kosher even according to R’ Yehoshua.
According to Abaye, we are still faced with our original problem: What is the difference between Yevamot 69a (version 1), where Shmuel rules that despite the admission of the father, the child may not marry a Jewess by birth, and Kesubos 14a, where the Gemara rules that when the father admits paternity, the child is kosher even according to R’ Yehoshua? Perhaps we can distinguish between the two cases as follows: That the expression “he cohabited” used there in Yevamot 69b, means he admits that he cohabited with her once and could have fathered the child. However, the expression “he admitted” used here where he said the child was “from me”,6Some commentators say that the expression used by the Gemara – אין מינאי proves that the Chosson is saying that the child is definitely mine. The Gemara could have simply used the word אין to indicate the Chosson’s admission that he cohabited with her. The use of the word מינאי - from me, indicates that he is certain the child is his, because he lived with his Kallah regularly. means that he is saying that he cohabited with her many times and that he was with her constantly, as [the Gemara] says when ruling that even though we know a married woman committed adultery, her child is kosher, because the majority of cohabitation is with her husband even though she may have cohabited with others. So too, here in Kesubos, we are speaking of a Chosson who is saying that he cohabited with his Kallah on a regular basis, as if he would be married to her. Here, we rule that the child is his, even according to R’ Yehoshua. There in Yevamot 69b (version 1) we are speaking of when the Chosson admits that he cohabited with her once and he could be the father. Abaye holds that even in the absence of rumors that she cohabited with others, we are concerned that she may have been with others and the child might be a mamzer. It is only according to Rabban Gamliel that we rule the child kosher, when his mother testifies that she was impregnated by her Chosson.

First, he admits [that he is the father]. In version 1 in Yevamot 69b the Gemara relates that the dispute between Rav and Shmuel is about when we know (by the Chosson’s admission) that he cohabited with her. Rava rules that if there are no rumors that she might have cohabited with others, her child is kosher. Abaye as we have seen disagrees.
In version 2 we have not heard from the Chosson. All we know is that she is presently pregnant. Rava rules that even if there are rumors that she was generally promiscuous, since there are also rumors that she cohabited with her Chosson, the child is kosher. Abaye holds that in face of rumors that she cohabited with others as well as teh Chosson, the child is not kosher.
According to רש"ש1I followed רש"ש with the explanation of this Tosfos. It seems a bit odd that Tosfos would ignore the distinction that he just made in the previous Tosfos, between the relatively minor admission of one cohabitation in Yevamot and the major admission of regular cohabitations here in Kesubos. our Tosfos is following the opinion of Rava there in Kesubos and is not taking into account the distinction that was made between the two different types of admission that was discussed at the conclusion of the previous Tosfos. According to the first version in Yevamot (69b) his admission is accepted only when there are no rumors that she was generally promiscuous. It is only then that Rava accepts the Chosson’s testimony about the paternity of the child, as is evident in the Gemara there. According to the other version, even if there are rumors that she was generally promiscuous, since the Chosson admits that he is the father, we attribute the child to him.

First, he admits. When we discover that a betrothed Kallah is pregnant, we must deal with two issues:
A) She obviously cohabited with a man and we do not know his identity. Did she become prohibited to her Chosson by cohabiting with another man?
B) What is the status of the child? Is he kosher and permitted to marry a Jewess by birth or is the child perhaps a mamzer and excluded from the Congregation of Hashem?
In Rav Yosef’s analysis of the question he says: what are we concerned about?
1) The Chosson admits that he fathered the child.
2) Even in the absence of his admission, we rule like Rabban Gamliel that we must believe the mother.
What is unclear in the Gemara is whether Rav Yosef was dealing with issue
A) whether the Chosson is permitted to live with his Kallah? or with issue
B) the status of the child.
Tosfos will examine both possibilities and conclude that Rav Yosef was dealing with the status of the child. We can explain that [the Gemara] is speaking about whether the Kallah is forbidden to the Chosson since she may have committed adultery during betrothal. The explanation is as follows: One reason for permitting the Kallah to the Chosson is that [the Chosson] admitted that he had relations with his Kallah and we know how she became pregnant. Therefore she does not become forbidden to him.
The next sentence in our Gemara becomes difficult when we say that it is addressed to the issue of whether the Kallah is forbidden to the Chosson or not. The Gemara presents Shmuel’s ruling that we follow Rabban Gamliel who says that we believe the mother as far as the legitimacy of the child is concerned.
But what is the Chosson saying? We do not have the option of saying that the Chosson is presently unavailable or has passed away as Tosfos will say in his second explanation of the Gemara, because we are dealing with issue A), whether the Kallah is permitted to him or not. He must be alive and available, otherwise there is no point in ruling on issue A). If so, what is he saying? Tosfos attempts to explain this sentence despite the inherent difficulties. And furthermore, even without the admission of the Chosson, Rav Yehudah etc. [said in the name of Shmuel that the halacha follows Rabban Gamliel]. [The Gemara] is not saying that even if the Chosson does not admit paternity, his Kallah will be permitted to him because we believe her, for if he does not admit paternity, and he is presently available, he must be saying that he did not cohabit with her,1It is noteworthy that Tosfos does not consider the option that the Chosson says nothing when questioned. Perhaps it is plain to Tosfos that even if the Chosson remains silent when asked if he fathered the child, it is tantamount to admitting that he did not. if so, it is certain that she is forbidden to him. She is pregnant and obviously cohabited with someone. The Chosson says it was not him. This is tantamount to saying that she committed adultery and she is therefore forbidden to the Chosson. Even if the bais din does not necessarily believe his word against the Kallah’s, she is forbidden to him, because he has rendered her by his own word as forbidden to himself.
Rather, what the Gemara means to say is that even when we cannot use his admission as proof of the paternity of the child, for example according to Abaye at the end of Perek Almanah (Yevamot 69b) who says: That since she was promiscuous in regard to the Chosson, she may have also been promiscuous in regard to others as well and his admission does not convince us that she cohabited only with her Chosson. According to this explanation, the Chosson is admitting paternity, however the bais din will not accept his admission as proof positive of paternity, because she may have cohabited with others.
According to Abaye we disregard his admission because it does not say enough. If so, how can we rule that she is permitted to him? Even so, she is not forbidden to him, because we believe her as Rabban Gamliel ruled that we believe a mother about the legitimacy of her child. So too, we believe her that she is permitted to her husband. The Gemara is ruling that despite our inability to establish paternity based on the Chosson’s admission, we can establish paternity on the testimony of the mother. This same concept applies to her permissibility to her husband. The Gemara is effectively saying that Abaye’s concern that the Kallah may have committed adultery with others is true only in the absence of her testimony to the opposite. However, if she does testify that she was not adulterous with others, we do believe her.
So did R’I explain the Gemara to us, but it is impossible to sustain [this explanation]. For according to [R’I’s] explanation, if this is correct, then that which Abaye said: That the Chosson’s admission does not convince us, for since she was promiscuous in regard to her Chosson she may have been promiscuous with others, that is so only when the mother was not investigated, because our Gemara is saying that when the Chosson’s admission is not sufficient to convince us, because of Abaye’s concern, we do rely on the testimony of the mother if available.
But this is not so! For Abaye’s statement was originally said in reference to the dispute between Rav and Shmuel about a Chosson who cohabited with his Kallah, where the Gemara in Kiddushin 75a interprets Shmuel’s use of the term “שתוקי-silenced” as meaning “בדוקי-investigated” - his mother was investigated and said that she cohabited with a kosher man. Even so, Abaye rules that we do not accept the admission of the father as proof positive of the paternity of the child. The Gemara in Kiddushin is clearly saying that even when the mother has been investigated and testified as to the paternity of her child, we still do not accept the admission of the Chosson. This conclusion contradicts R’I’s explanation of our Gemara.
The explanation of Shmuel’s use of the term “שתוקי” as “בדוקי-investigated” is mentioned in Kiddushin 75a. According to Tosfos text that Gemara is speaking about “one who cohabited with his betrothed”. It is known to us by his admission that he had relations with his Kallah. It is in reference to that case, that Abaye in Yevamot 69b voices his concern that the Chosson’s admission is insufficient evidence.
Tosfos has shown that the Gemara there is speaking of when the mother has been investigated. We have both father and mother saying that the Chosson is the father and even so Abaye does not accept this as evidence. This of course contradicts R’I who says that when the father’s admission is insufficient because of Abaye’s concern, we will accept the testimony of the mother.
However, as Tosfos mentioned earlier on 13b ד"ה חדא דקא מודה, most manuscripts of the Gemara in Kiddushin have an alternate text. Our Gemara in Kiddushin follows the alternate text. Tosfos will now concede, that his refutation of R’I is only valid according to his text. According to most manuscripts, the Gemara in Kiddushin 75a presents no problem to R’I.
According to the texts in Kiddushin that read: A betrothed Kallah who became pregnant, there is no difficulty to R’I. The Gemara there which indicates that we do not accept the mother’s testimony according to Abaye is speaking of when we have not heard from the Chosson at all. All we know is that the Kallah had relations with someone, but we have no idea who it was. The Chosson is either deceased or unavailable. We are working exclusively with the mother’s testimony. It may very well be, that if both Chosson and Kallah testified that the Chosson was the father, we would believe them. There is no contradiction to R’I.
Therefore, in order to understand how Tosfos’ text in the Gemara in Kiddushin can be reconciled with our Gemara, we must abandon R’I’s explanation, and we need to explain that here in Kesubos 14a, [the Gemara] is not speaking about whether [the Kallah] is forbidden to [the Chosson]. Rather, the issue discussed is about the legitimacy of the child. Saying that we are not discussing whether the Kallah is permissible to the Chosson or not, gives us the flexibility of saying that the Chosson is not present, as Tosfos will now say.
The Chosson may make one of two statements:
a) The child is mine.
b) I did not cohabit with her and the child is not mine.
There is a third option:
c) The Chosson is saying nothing because he is either deceased or unavailable and the the bais din will have to rule on the legitimacy of the child without his input.
And now, that we have explained that the issue in the Gemara is the legitimacy of the child, the “sugu-and furthermore” introducing a second reason for ruling that the child is legitimate, can be understood simply. The Gemara is saying: Furthermore, even if the father does not admit paternity, this does not mean that he said: b) the child is not his. For if this was so Rabban Gamliel would not rule that the child is kosher, since this would be a case of the mother claiming that she is certain that the child is her Chosson’s, versus the Chosson claiming that the child is certainly not his, as [the Gemara] says in the beginning of the second Perek, that Rabban Gamliel’s ruling that we believe the mother is only when the mother’s claim is certain and the opposition is uncertain.
If so, what is the Chosson claiming? Rather, we are speaking of c) [the Chosson] passed away or he is not available for us to interrogate him.
The Gemara says that in the situation under discussion we may rule leniently, because it is post facto. If as Tosfos originally thought, we are discussing whether the Kallah is permitted to the Chosson, we can understand that the question is post facto, because they are already betrothed. However, if we are discussing the legitimacy of the child, why is this considered ‘post facto’, the child is not yet in a marriage? That which [the Gemara] will soon consider this question of the legitimacy of the child as post facto, that is because the child will never be able to marry a Jewess by birth if we rule that we do not accept the mother’s testimony because a mamzer may not enter into the Congregation of Hashem. Furthermore, he would even be forbidden to marry a mamzeress, for by Torah law he is kosher and forbidden to marry a mamzeress.2By Torah law, we have no basis to declare the child a mamzer. There is absolutely no evidence that his mother was an adulterer and we would rule that he is kosher. All the concerns in our Gemara about the paternity of the child are Rabbinic. Even if we are concerned that he might be a mamzer and Rabbincally forbid him from marrying a Jewess by birth, we cannot permit him to marry a mamzeress, for she is prohibited to him by Torah law.
(From 13Bf - תוס' ד"ה ההוא ארוס, until here was missing from the Tosfos.)

A widow of uncertain status. עיסה - literally - dough. It is used in our Gemara as a description of an uncertain status. The widow of ‘eesa’ refers to a woman who married into this uncertain status and may possibly have become disqualified from marrying a Kohain. Tosfos will argue that the concept of עיסה - refers specifically to a family where there is a doubt about whether a chalal married into the family. Rashi translates עיסה as a doubt.
Rashi offers of two explanations of אלמנת עיסה - literally, the widow of a doubt, which the Gemara refers to as double doubt:
There was a divorce, whose results were in doubt. The husband threw a ‘get’ to his wife. It is uncertain whether it landed closer to her or closer to her husband. We are uncertain whether she is a divorcee or not. Subsequently, her first husband died and she then married a Kohain. Is her son by this second marriage a chalal or not. This depends on whether, she was a divorcee or not.
A) The doubt happened to the mother of this dubious chalal, and she was forbidden to marry a Kohain only because of a doubt. This widow of her son who is now in doubt because of her son is referred to as a double doubt, because the original doubt did not happen to her. Her status is merely an extension of the original doubt.
B) From the words of R’ Yosef Tuv Elem I found that the meaning of - widow of ‘eesa’ - is as follows: A woman whose deceased husband was himself a case of double doubt. For example: His mother’s divorce from her first husband was doubtful. Perhaps the thrown get landed closer to him, perhaps it landed closer to her. [The first husband] died within three months and she was married to a Kohain within those three months, and she gave birth to this son.
The doubts are as follows:
Perhaps he was a ninth month son of the first husband who was also a Kohain, and he is kosher, even if she was divorced, for 1) she conceived before the divorce. Or even 2) if she conceived after the divorce, but her first husband was a Yisrael and not a Kohain. In either of these cases [the son] is not a chalal. On the other hand, perhaps he was a seven month son of the last husband and he is the son of a Kohain and he is a dubious chalal. This is a double doubt: Perhaps he is not the son of a Kohain, and even if he is the son of a Kohain, perhaps his mother was not a divorcee, but a widow.
Tosfos will first show why he rejects both explanations of Rashi. Rashi offered two explanation and both are awkward. Let us remember that in both of Rashi’s explanation, the halachic doubt about the person, is specifically about a known person. Our doubt is about his status. For [the Gemara] says later on 14b: Who is the widow of eesa? whoever was mixed in with a dubious chalal.
But what is the relevance of the term ‘mixed in’, when discussing a woman who was married to a dubious chalal? There is no mixture. We know exactly to whom she was married. Our doubt is only about his satus. Furthermore, the expression ‘dough’ as a symbol of doubt, is not applicable to one person. Rather, it is applicable when speaking of a family, as [the Gemara] says (Kiddushin 69b): All lands are like ‘dough’ in comparison to Eretz Yisrael, and Eretz Yisrael is like ‘dough’ in comparison to Babylonia.

[The two opinions of] Rabbi Yehoshua are not contradictory. Abaye asked that there is a contradiction between
A) R’ Yehoshua in our Mishna of Kesubos 13a where he does not accept the word of a pregnant young lady who insists that the father of her fetus is a man who does not disqualify her from Kehunah and
B) the Mishna in Eduyos 8, 3, where R’ Yehoshua says that the widow of ‘עיסה-dough’ is permissible to a Kohain despite the fact that we are unaware of the status of her deceased husband.
Abaye resolved the contradiction as follows:
A) Our Mishna in Kesubos 13a is speaking of a young lady who had a promiscuous affair with the father of her fetus. In the midst of promiscuity, she does not investigate the status of her partner.
B) The Mishna in Eduoyos 8, 3, is speaking of a woman who was legitimately married to her ‘עיסה-dough’ husband. We may assume that she investigated his status prior to her marriage.
Rava disagreed with Abaye’s understanding of the contradiction between the Mishnayos of Kesubos and Eduyos. He points out that just as there is a contradiction between the two opinions of R’ Yehoshua, there is also a contradiction between the two opinions of Rabon Gamliel. In order to reconcile the contradiction between the two opinions of Rabon Gamliel, Rava said that in our
A) Mishna of Kesubos we are speaking of a woman who claims that she is certain that her partner was legitimate.
B) The Mishna of Eduyos is speaking of a situation where the widow is uncertain about the status of her deceased husband.
Rava also offers an alternative resolution of the contradiction between the two opinions of R’ Yehoshua:
A) Our Mishna of Kesubos is speaking of when there is only one doubt about the legitimacy of the child’s father.
B) The Mishna in Eduyos is speaking of when there was a double doubt.
But why was it necessary for Rava to offer an alternative resolution for the contradiction between the two opinions of R’ Yehoshua? Does he disagree with Abaye’s explanation that when a woman marries she usually investigates the status of her husband? Now, [Rava] could not have answered that the reason for R’ Yehoshua’s leniency in Eduyos is because a woman who marries first investigates the status of her proposed husband’s legitimacy and then marries as [Abaye] answered earlier. Why not? Because now in order to resolve the contradiction between the two opinions of Rabon Gamliel we need to interpret the Mishna in Eduyos as speaking of when the widow is claiming ‘perhaps’, for she is also uncertain about the status of her deceased husband. We cannot say that we can rely on her investigation of her husband prior to her marriage when she herself is claiming that she doesn't truly know the status of her husband. Thus, it was necessary for Rava to find a resolution for R’ Yehoshua that conforms with the way the Mishna was interpreted to resolve the contradiction of Rabon Gamliel.
Our Mishna in Kesubos 13a is speaking of when there is only one doubt about the status of the young lady’s partner and we must therefore be stringent.
B) The Mishna in Eduyos 8, 3, is speaking of when there is a double doubt about the status of the deceased husband and that is why R’ Yehoshua is lenient.

The Rabbis taught: who is the 'widow of dough'? The Gemara earlier quoted a Mishna in Eduyos 8, 3, that discusses אלמנה עיסה literally the ‘widow of עיסה-dough’. According to Tosfos אלמנה עיסה the discussion is about a woman who married a member of a family among whom there are one or some dubious chalalim. According to Rashi, that Mishna is speaking of a woman who was married to an individual who is a dubious chalal. Since the translation of this term is somewhat ambiguous, I will always refer to her as ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ or as ‘widow of dough’.
The Mishna spoke of the testimony of R’ Yehoshua that this woman is permitted to marry a Kohain. The Gemara now introduces a second Baraisa that according to our text also speaks of אלמנה עיסה. Towards the end of this Gemara we will learn that R’ Yose also agrees to the essential ruling of this Baraisa that a ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ is fit to marry a Kohain.
Rabbeinu Tam cites a Gemara in Kiddushin 75a, where it appears that R’ Yose does not hold that אלמנה עיסה is permissible to a Kohain. We will soon quote that Gemara. Rabbeinu Tam suggests that the text of the present Gemara should not read “who is the widow of dough?”, but rather, “who is dough?”
The term ‘עיסה-dough’ according to Rabbeinu Tam refers to the members of the family in question and not to a woman who was married to a member of the family. This member may be a male or a female. The issue is clearly whether the family has the disqualification of being mamzerin, nasinim, slaves, chalalim or not. Within this Tosfos, we sometimes refer to the individual as a female, she is called ‘daughter’ and sometimes in the context of Tosfos, we refer to ‘him’ a male. Essentially, there is no difference. I will always speak of the ‘daughter’ in a quotation mark as a reminder, that this is not necessarily a ruling that applies exclusively to the females of the family, but to the males as well.
We must also keep in mind that when we speak of the ‘widow of עיסה-dough’, the intent is that she may have become disqualified because she had relations with the person in question. Usually, this is true of a widow married to that person. The same is however also true of a woman who was raped or seduced by the individual in question, even if they were not married.
In summation: I will speak of
A) ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ which refers to a woman married to a dubious chalal,
B) ‘עיסה-dough’, which refers to a family whose lineage is suspicious. This may be a male or a female. We will refer to the female as ‘daughter’.
C) ‘Widow’ refers to any woman who had physical relations with a person whose lineage is in doubt, whether she was married to him or not.
The Gemara says in Kiddushin 74b: The Rabonon taught a Baraisa: A boy who is nine years and a day old, who is an Amonite, Moabite, Egyptian or Edomite convert, or a Cuthean, nasin, chalal or mamzer, who cohabited with a woman who was either the daughter of a Kohain, Levi or Yisrael, disqualifies her. This is the opinion of the first Tanna. R’ Yose says: Anyone whose progeny is unfit such as an Amonite or Moabite convert renders [the woman with whom he cohabits] unfit. Anyone whose progeny is not unfit, such as a second generation Egyptian or Edomite, whose children may marry into the Jewish people, does not render [a woman with whom he cohabits] unfit.
Rabon Shimon ben Gamliel says: Anyone whose daughter you may marry, such as an Amonite or Moabite convert, you may marry his widow. Anyone whose daughter you may not marry, you may not marry his widow.
A bit later in Kiddushin 75a, Rav Chisda says: All, the first Tanna, R’ Yose and Rabon Shimon ben Gamliel, agree that a ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ is unfit to Kehunah. Who is the most lenient among these Tannaim? Rabon Shimon ben Gamliel. He says: Anyone, whose daughter you are allowed to marry, you are permitted to marry his widow. Anyone, whose daughter you are not allowed to marry, you may not marry his widow. What does this statement of Rav Chisda exclude? It excludes the ‘widow of עיסה-dough’, for she is unfit to Kehunah.
It is very clear that all of the disputants in the Baraisa of 74b, including R’ Yose, hold that it is forbidden to marry the ‘widow of עיסה-dough’. This is definitely contradicts our Gemara where R’ Yose seems to say that a ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ is permitted. Rabbeinu Tam has a difficulty with the text of the manuscripts that read ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ as does the text in our Gemara. For if so, that the text is ‘widow of עיסה’, then R’ Yose holds that a ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ is fit to marry a Kohain, because he rules that a person who is silent when accused of being a mamzer is fit to marry into the Jewish people, despite the accusation that he is a mamzer, then certainly1See רש"ש. Also see Rashi יד: ד"ה כל שאין בה. Rashi is explaining the position of the first Tanna, who holds that any family that is accused of being mamzerim etc. and responds with silence is not kosher. But the Baraisa initially said - who is the ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ that R’ Yehoshua spoke of? The Baraisa certainly means that there is a ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ who is eligible. Yet the first Tanna speaks only of a family that is ineligible. Who is the ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ that is eligible. Rashi explains: But who is the ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ that was ruled fit? That is the wife of a dubious chalal, whose doubt we are aware of. His mother was the recipient of a doubtful divorce.But a family that we do not recognize and we hear that someone calls them unfit and the response is silence, they are unfit. Rashi understands that even the first Tanna who says that any response of silence renders the family unfit, holds that a woman whose husband was a dubious chalal is permissible to a Kohain. R’ Yose who is more lenient than the first Tanna, rules that even when one responds with silence to charges that his family are mamzerin, the family is ruled eligible certainly holds that the widow of a dubious chalal is permissible. However, according to Rabbeinu Tam’s explanation, our Baraisa is only discussing a family that is accused of being illegitimate. It is judged by the response of the accused. It is not discussing a woman who was married to a dubious chalal at all, and we have no indication whatsoever from this Baraisa about a woman who was married to a dubious chalal. See מהרש"א מהר"ם שיף and פני יהושע he rules that a ‘widow of עיסה’ is fit, as is evident in the flow of [the Gemara]. Whereas, in Perek Asarah Yuchsin (ibid.) [the Gemara] clearly says that according to R’ Yose a ‘widow of עיסה-dough’ is unfit to marry a Kohain.
There definitely is a contradiction between the Gemara in Kesubos 14a and Kiddushin 75a.2See שיטה מקובצת who quotes ריטב"א who answers that since R’ Yose is not mentioned within our Baraisa, but rather in some other Baraisa, it may be that he only stated that if a person is silent when accused of being a mamzer, he is ruled fit. This does not at all indicate his position about a woman who is a ‘widow of עיסה-dough’. The indication that a ‘widow of dough’ is permitted is only from those opinions mentioned within the Baraisa. See previous note. Therefore Rabbeinu Tam erases the word אלמנה-widow of’ and emends the text as follows: Who is ‘עיסה-dough’? The Baraisa is addressing a ‘daughter’ of an עיסה family. It is not speaking about a woman who was married to a dubious chalal. This Baraisa refers to that Tosefta 3, 3, which we learned at the end of Eduyos: The ‘עיסה-dough’ is believed to establish that a family is pure or impure, to push away or draw near, to establish prohibition or admissibility. This is the explanation of the Tosefta: We believe a ‘daughter’ of this family to purify herself by protesting or remaining silent, according to one master as he holds and according to the other master as he holds. There is a difference of opinion within the Baraisa as to whom we believe when they do not protest and who is believed specifically when they do protest.
Tosfos explains the six rulings mentioned in Tosefta: The expression: to render impure or pure is relevant insofar as illegitimacy and being a nasin is concerned, as we learned in a Mishna in Kiddushin (72b): Mamzerim and nasinim will eventually become pure in the future. We see that the word purity or impurity is used in reference to mamzerim and nasinim. The expression: to push away or draw near is relevant to being a chalal, as we learned in the Mishna in Eduyos 8, 3,: The Kohanim will listen to you to push away a family of questionable genealogy, but not to draw near a family whose lineage is questionable. So too, below (27a) we learned in reference to a young lady who pledged herself as security for a debt that was subsequently not paid and she became the property of the idolater creditors: the family members pushed her away. The phrase “push away” is used to describe a woman who is not permitted to marry a Kohain. The phrase: to render prohibited or admissible is relevant to those who might be slaves.
Tosfos questions the use of the expression “to render pure or impure” in regard to the status of a family. His objection is based on the Gemara later on 28b. The Rabanan taught in a Baraisa: We believe a youngster who says: This is what my father said to me: This family is pure, that family is impure.
Can it enter your mind that [the child] is saying: the family is pure or impure? Pure and impure is not usually used to describe a family’s status. The Gemara answers: Rather, what the Baraisa means is that the child is saying, this family is fit and that family is unfit. It is evident from this Gemara that pure and impure are not proper descriptions of a family’s status. This contradicts Tosfos’ explanation that pure and impure are descriptions of its status insofar as mamzerim and nasinim are concerned.
That which [the Gemara] asks in the second Perek (below 28b) when discussing a family’s status, can it enter upon your mind that a child is saying: a family is impure or pure? It seems from the Gemara’s question that pure or impure is not an accurate description of a family’s status. That question was asked there because there the Baraisa is including all disqualifications in one phrase. He should have expressed it: This family is fit and that family is unfit. However, when the discussion is solely whether the family might be mamzerim of nasinim, the description pure or impure is truly relevant.
Tosfos will now explain how the phrase “she is believed” is meant in this Baraisa that discusses the ‘עיסה-dough’ meaning a daughter of the family, as opposed to the ‘widow’ of this dough family. The expression “she is believed” is used because of the positive aspects of these issues which are to purify one suspected of being of a mamzer family, to draw near one suspected of being of a chalal family and to permit one suspected of being of a slave family.
